title: Skeleton
description: Use to show a placeholder while content is loading.

body.raw:
## Installation Install via CLI: ```bash npx @sickui/cli add skeleton ``` ### Manual Installation If you prefer to install manually, copy and paste the following code into your project. ```bash npm install class-variance-authority clsx tailwind-merge ``` ## Usage
); }`}> ## Variants Use the `variant` prop to change the visual style of the Skeleton.

Default

Shimmer

); }`}> ## Examples ### Card Skeleton Perfect for loading states of card components.
); }`}> ### Loading State A comprehensive loading state example showing profile, content, and action skeletons. {/* Profile skeleton */}
{/* Content skeleton */}
{/* Button skeleton */} ); }`}> ## API Reference ### Skeleton | Prop | Type | Default | Description | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `variant` | `"default" \| "shimmer"` | `"default"` | The visual variant of the skeleton | | `className` | `string` | `undefined` | Additional CSS classes | ## Accessibility The Skeleton component includes: - **Semantic markup**: Uses appropriate ARIA attributes for loading states - **Reduced motion**: Respects user's motion preferences - **Screen reader support**: Properly announced as loading content ## Common Patterns ### Text Skeleton ```tsx
``` ### Avatar Skeleton ```tsx ``` ### Button Skeleton ```tsx ``` ### Image Skeleton ```tsx ``` ## Best Practices 1. **Match dimensions**: Make skeleton dimensions similar to actual content 2. **Use appropriate shapes**: Round skeletons for avatars, rectangular for text 3. **Maintain layout**: Prevent layout shifts when content loads 4. **Consider animation**: Use shimmer variant sparingly to avoid distraction 5. **Accessibility**: Always provide loading indicators for screen readers
